thread.title: 7 things to know today, plus secret government map shows China cyber attacks in Fla., across the U.S.
thread.title_full: 7 things to know today, plus secret government map shows China cyber attacks in Fla., across the U.S.

author: Cindy Barth
title: 7 things to know today, plus secret government map shows China cyber attacks in Fla., across the U.S.
text: 7 things to know today, plus secret government map shows China cyber attacks in Fla., across the U.S. Jul 31, 2015, 7:11am EDT Industries & Tags Cindy Barth Editor Orlando Business Journal Home of the Day Thinkstock So here's an interesting item that will make you go, "Hmmm" this Friday morning. A classified U.S. intelligence map that shows computer hacks by China to almost 700 public and private targets in the U.S. includes a number of attacks in Florida. The National Security Agency map obtained by NBC News includes a red dot for each successful “computer intrusion” of a corporate, private or U.S. government target over a five-year period, the network said. The FBI said the Chinese are targeting power and telecommunications systems, as well as private individuals. The agency is investigating hundreds of attacks across the U.S. The map was part of a NSA briefing prepared by the NSA Threat Operations Center in February 2014, an intelligence source told NBC News. The briefing highlighted China's interest in Google and defense contractors such as Lockheed Martin , and in air traffic control systems, the network reports. The state with the most attacks, according to the map, is California. And be sure to check out these other Friday headlines: Lake Mary tech firm signs deal with Merlin Entertainments Accesso Technology Group Plc. of Lake Mary has inked a seven-year deal with Merlin Entertainments Group to provide on-site ticketing and e-commerce solutions across the operator's global portfolio. The installation of Accesso's solutions will take place over three years and include more than 100 attractions around the world, including Merlin's Legoland Parks, Madame Tussauds, Sea Life and The Eye brand. "We have a great deal of confidence that Accesso's next-generation ticketing solution will improve the online guest booking journey for our guests and play a key role in our long term growth initiatives," said Nick Varney , Merlin Entertainments CEO. Florida Legislators unsure how to go about redistricting After reaching an agreement this week with voting-rights groups, Florida lawmakers face the chore of going into special session in October to redraw Senate districts. But the agreement with the League of Women Voters of Florida, Common Cause Florida and others that legally challenged the Senate's current map doesn't list the districts that have to be changed. And the opponents' objections have encompassed 28 districts — fully 70 percent of the districts represented in the 40-member Senate. A joint memo issued Tuesday by Senate President Andy Gardiner, R-Orlando, and House Speaker Steve Crisafulli, R-Merritt Island, didn't give many specifics. It simply said the Legislature's staff will draw a map "that complies with the Florida Supreme Court's ruling [on the congressional districts] and all other relevant legal standards." Read more here from the Jacksonville Business Journal . Analyst: Moynihan is the right man for BofA If you ask Dick Bove , he'll tell you Brian Moynihan is just the guy to run Bank of America Corp. (NYSE: BAC), the second-largest bank in Central Florida. The equity research analyst at Rafferty Capital Markets has been supportive of BofA for years. And yesterday Bove wrote about Moynihan’s success as CEO of the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank in an op-ed column for CNBC . “This [banking] knowledge, combined with a keen intellect, allowed him to achieve the almost impossible when he took over as CEO of Bank of America in 2010 in what arguably were the darkest days in the bank's almost 200 years of existence,” Bove wrote. The column comes a week after BofA announced a series of management changes . Bove argues that those changes are a good sign that the second-largest bank in the country is moving toward revenue growth. Read more here . 30-year mortgage rates back below 4 percent After hovering above 4 percent for six consecutive weeks, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell back below 4 percent this week, and rates aren’t likely to move much in the next several weeks, according to Freddie Mac (OTC: FMCC). Freddie Mac’s weekly rate report says the average rate on a 30-year fix in the week ending July 30 was 3.98 percent, down from 4.04 percent last week. A year ago, 30-year rates averaged 4.12 percent. A 15-year fix averaged 3.17 percent this week, down from 3.21 percent. A one-year adjustable-rate mortgage averaged 2.52 percent, down from 2.54 percent. Trending this morning on Google Business
